fields.description:
A user with only *View* and *Build* permissions can navigate to a completed build's page, select a job for that build and then click on {{Actions >> Disable Job}} to disable that job. It is also possible to disable a Plan from the Plan Summary page and a Plan Branch. That should require *Edit* capability at minimum.

This is also *not* logged to the {{Plan Configuration >> Audit log}} page, so there's no way to trace a user that disabled a plan or branch via the UI. The only information that is logged in the {{Audit log}} page in the latest versions of Bamboo is related to the job being enabled/disabled.
fields.summary: Users with View and Build permissions should not be able to disable Plans, Branches and Jobs

fields.description:
Our build plan consists of 2 stages: a standard build & UT stage and then an integration test stage. The integration test stage consists of multiple plans to parallelize the tests. 

The problem is that due to the nature of setting up a complicated integration environment, the integration stage jobs occasionally fail for reasons not directly related to the code being tested. In these situations we would like to be able to rerun *just* those jobs (other jobs that ran successfully but had failed tests should not be re-executed.

This is actually similar to what was asked for in BAM-7549 but the "resolution" to that issue didn't quite match the description. Being able to re-run all of the failures inside a plan is useful in some cases but is insufficient for this purpose.
fields.summary: Allow re-running a single job within a plan

fields.description:
The "Daily" and "Days per week" trigger schedule doesn't let you change the minutes field from "00" when choosing an Interval any of:
- every 15 minutes
- every 30 minutes
- every hour
- every 2 hours
- every 3 hours

This prevents you from spreading multiple triggers across the hour.
fields.summary: Allow specifying minutes in trigger schedule
Including POM files into Elastic Image distribution files

https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Integrating+Bamboo+with+Bitbucket+Server
fields.summary: DOCUMENTATION: Specify Bitbucket Server requires SSH be enabled for Bamboo integration features

fields.description:
h4. Problem
When manually deleting a plan in Bamboo the corresponding filesystem directories for the project are not removed. 
* <bamboo-home>/artifacts/PROJ-PLAN
* <bamboo-home>/xml-data/builds/PROJ-PLAN

h4. Duplication Steps
# Create a project / plan (i.e.: PROJ-PLAN)
# Add a repository into the plan
# Add a *Script task* to build plan:
{noformat}
if [ ! -d "foo" ]; then
   mkdir foo
   echo "foo" > foo/foo.txt
fi
{noformat}
# Create a "{{Artifact definition}}":
|Name|*Foo*|
|Location| |
|Copy pattern|*\*\*/\**|
# Push a new commit into the repository
# Wait for it to be triggered automatically (do not run it manually)
# Repeat step 5-6
# Delete plan
# Restart Bamboo (restarting Bamboo will initiate the deletion of the folder immediately)

h4. Expectation
Bamboo should remove filesystem directories as well as database references to deleted build plan. It makes the warning before deletion false, as this information is only removed from the UI and database.
{quote}
You are about to delete plan "PROJ - PLAN" and all of its branches. This plan has x branches, x stage and x job. If you proceed with this action Bamboo will irrevocably delete all branches, configurations, artifacts, logs and results related to this plan.
{quote}

h4.Notes
* <bamboo-home>/xml-data/builds/PROJ-PLAN/download-data/build_logs/PROJ-PLAN-#.log is the log for change detection, for example:
{noformat}
simple	18-Dec-2018 23:00:56	Change detection found 1 change, starting build PROJ-PLAN-3
{noformat}
* Change detection log may take a while before it is populated with the above message

h4. Workaround
Remove the remaining files manually
fields.summary: Delete plan action does not remove certain build logs and artifacts from BAMBOO_HOME

fields.description: We've had commits mentioning JIRA tickets that have since been moved to a new project.  Bamboo is recognizing the JIRA tickets (and creating hyperlinks for them), but cannot find the details for the ticket itself.  If you click on the link, it takes you to the valid ticket (in the new project), so the information is there, Bamboo just doesn't know how to get it.
fields.summary: Bamboo doesn't understand JIRA issues that have moved projects

fields.description:
The fix for BAM-12208 implemented a very broad output censorship rule: if there's any variable with "password" in its name, then that variable's value is considered to be sensitive information and any appearance of it in a build task's output is replaced by asterisks.

The problem is that this happens regardless of whether the variable has anything to do with the current build plan. Some other Bamboo user could define a global variable called {{silly.password}} whose value is "test", and now even though my build task doesn't reference {{bamboo.silly.password}} at all, every occurrence of "test" in my output will be asterisked out— which isn't necessarily a disaster, but is at least very confusing and hard to diagnose.
fields.summary: Build output is being obfuscated due to someone else's unrelated "password" global variable
Pre-Post Build Command Runner - Environment variable issues

28-Sep-2015 17:11:28	Could not connect to http://localhost:8123/service, giving up after 120 seconds
28-Sep-2015 17:11:28	Finished task 'Docker Run task' with result: Success
{noformat}

fields.description:
Currently the SCP task only has one field that acts as both the base path and pattern. This can result in some odd issues with transferring of files in a set path structure. For example:

Task Configuration:
Local Path: support/lib/**
Destination Path: /tools/support/UTILITIES/lib/

After deployment:
Result: /tools/support/UTILITIES/lib/support/lib/... 

It would be great if these could be separated so each can be individually defined.
fields.summary: Separate base path and pattern for the deployment SCP task

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When editing the Elastic Bamboo Configuration in Cloud Bamboo instances, the following message is under the 'maximum number of elastic agents' configuration:
{noformat}
Your license edition will be adjusted automatically to allow your maximum number of elastic agents.
{noformat}

Changing the maximum number of agents seems to locally change the license information under the 'Licence Details' page (though not always), due to [this bug|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-16078] and it seems that the customer can create more agents, in this case. However, the customer's license is not actually updated.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
#  Go to the Configuration page in Bamboo

h3. Expected Results
# The misleading message is not there (and bug BAM-16078 is fixed)
# Or, the message is there and the license is actually updated 

h3. Actual Results
* License details page is updated (this actually seem to be intermittent)
* It is possible to create more agents now, even more than previous license
* The license itself is not updated
 

h3.Workaround
None so far
fields.summary: Wrong message in Elastic Bamboo Configuration

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Agent becomes offline if the build is stopped in a certain timing.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
(!) Please note that this is not 100% reproducible. You might need to try this 10 times to reproduce the problem.
# Install vanilla Linux OS (I used CentOS 6.6 64bit)
# Install JDK 7 (I used 1.7.0_79) on it
# Install Bamboo 5.9.4 on it
# Create a _project_ and a _plan_
# Create any task in the plan (I just created a _Script_ task that only executes {{exit 0}})
# Put some heavy load on the server (i.e. I ran [_stress_|http://people.seas.harvard.edu/~apw/stress/] - {{$ stress --cpu 2 --vm 1 --vm-bytes 128M}})
# Start the plan under the heavy load and stop it right after then.
# Agent becomes offline.

h3. Expected Results
Agent does not become offline

h3. Actual Results
The below exception is thrown in the atlassian-bamboo.log file when the problem occurs. I enabled debug log, but nothing detail came out:
{noformat}
2015-07-01 20:45:43,398 INFO [10-BAM::Default Agent::Agent:pool-25-thread-1] [BuildAgentControllerImpl] Agent 'Default Agent' ready to take build from queue...
2015-07-01 20:45:43,398 WARN [10-BAM::Default Agent::Agent:pool-25-thread-1] [BuildAgentControllerImpl] Building interrupted. Stopping agent 'Default Agent'...
2015-07-01 20:45:43,398 INFO [10-BAM::Default Agent::Agent:pool-25-thread-1] [DefaultBuildAgent] Changing context: null -> null on Default Agent/3f8c246e
2015-07-01 20:45:43,398 INFO [10-BAM::Default Agent::Agent:pool-25-thread-1] [DefaultBuildAgent] Build agent 'Default Agent' stopped.
{noformat}

h3.Workaround
There is no workaround reported so far
fields.summary: Agent becomes offline if the build is stopped in a certain timing

fields.description:
h3. Summary
After release 5.10-OD-04-007, several builds are reporting errors when publishing artifacts.
The error: *"Unable to publish artifact"* appears in the logs.

h3. Environment
Bamboo Cloud 5.10-OD-04-007 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
Not all conditions that cause this problem are known
# Try running an existing plan that has artifacts to publish

h3. Expected Results
Build runs and artifacts are published.

h3. Actual Results
These errors are present in the logs
{noformat}
Unable to publish artifact [Artifact]: Unable to publish artifact Shared artifact: [Artifact], pattern: [**] anchored at: [.] for ABC-DEFG-JOB1-10 via com.atlassian.bamboo.build.artifact.BambooRemoteArtifactHandler@53e23eb7
{noformat}
 
h3. Notes
The problem is only affecting local artifact storage.
Remote AWS S3 storage is not affected.

h3.Workaround
*Fix*
Contact Atlassian Support for a fix. This requires a restart in Bamboo.

*Temporary workaround*
As a temporary workaround option, you can enable S3 Artifact Storage to publish artifacts to Amazon S3.
Please note that switching to S3 will incur in additional charges by Amazon.
For more information on Amazon Pricing please visit: [Amazon S3 Pricing|https://aws.amazon.com/s3/pricing/]
fields.summary: After 5.10-OD-4.1 release, some artifacts are failing to be published

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Since this week's release (09/28/2015) artifact's folders are being published as links, not as folders (full path link until the file instead of links to each folder)

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Generate an artifact which file is within some folders

h3. Expected Results
Each folder within the artifact should be a link to the next folder within the tree until the final file is reached. e.g.
{code}--folder1
      |_folder2
             |_folder3
                    |_file.ext{code}
h3. Actual Results
The first level within the artifact is a full link to the file directly. e.g.
{code}folder1\folder2\folder3\file.ext{code}
h3. Notes
I believe this is due to the back slashes in the path since we run a Linux environment on Cloud which considers forward slashes.
This seems to only impact Window instances.
h3.Workaround
No Workaround yet.
fields.summary: Artifact folders produced on Windows are being published as files

fields.description:
If the agent receives a 500 response code back from the server, the retry handling logic in Apache HTTP client is not invoked and the failure is permanent.

Provide a system property that allows this behaviour to be overridden and retry a couple of times if the server returns a 500.

fields.description:
h3. Steps to reproduce

# View the activity history/recent builds page of an online agent that has run more than 25 builds.
# Ensure the page is set to "Showing Last 25 builds" (which is the default).

h3. Actual results

Note that at the bottom of the page the pagination section:
- it reports "Showing 1-25 of 25", and
- the "next" and "last" arrow links do not link to anything.

Changing the results list to show "All builds" will show the actual number of builds (i.e. the true number, which is higher than 25) and the "next" and "last" arrows will work.

This is deceptive and confusing because the user thinks that the 25th build at the bottom of the list is the first build the agent ran, even though this is not the case. This makes debugging agent problems very frustrating.

h3. Expected results

The pagination section should report the correct total number of builds (e.g. "Showing 1-25 of 452"  and the "next" and "last" icons should link to the respective pages.

Note that other view options ("Showing X days", or "All builds") do not have any problem.


Bamboo version: 5.10.0-m27
fields.summary: An agent's activity history lies about total number of builds

fields.description:
The Docker task does not allow using variables to point to the name of the image to be used for the task. 

The repository field in the "Build a Docker Image" and "Push a Docker image to a Docker registry" commands prevents the ${variable} syntax from being entered, as it does not meet the regex requirements for a Docker repository name.

The Docker image field in the "Run a Docker container" command does allow the ${variable} syntax, but does not substitute the variable when attempting to run the container, and the Docker daemon returns an error.
fields.summary: Docker task should allow variables to be used in the docker image/repository name

fields.description: We send an update for every repo in a build. We should only send one update per Stash instance, not repo instance.
fields.summary: Bamboo sends suprious build status updates to Stash

fields.description: Currently only Bamboo administrators can reorder the build queue.  It would be great if there was a global permission to permit a user the right reorder the build queue without having to grant them all the other rights of an administrator.
fields.summary: Decouple Reorder Build Queue permission from Bamboo administrator Role

fields.description: Currently if a build logs infinitely or even excessively the files grow unbounded and this will cause the agents to crash. If Bamboo could monitor the size of those logs at a configurable size this crash could be avoided.
fields.summary: Allow Bamboo to monitor build log size and stop builds when their logs grow too large

fields.description: We have a few tools that produce different exit codes depending on their outcome and we would like to choose if a particular set of exit codes means a success or failure for our tasks.  I understand we can create a script to wrap our commands to the tool and return 0 or 1 based on our conditions, but I feel this would be better served inside the Bamboo task to make it more visible and useful.
fields.summary: Custom success / failure conditions for exit codes

fields.description:
In Order to be able to add a new experimental agent to my agent pool
As a bamboo Adminstrator
I want to be able to set a capability to my experimental agent, which I can check for absent on my jobs.

Scenario: Production critical Jobs
Given There is a Job
And there are no Agents
And I add a new experimental agent with capability "experimental1"
And I set as a requirement for my Job: Capability: experimental1 status:"does not exist"
When I run my Job
Then there should be no agents capable to build this job

Scenario: Experimental Jobs
Given There is a Job
And there are no Agents
And I add a new experimental agent with capability "experimental1"
And I set as a requirement for my Job: Capability: experimental1 status:"does not exist"
When I run my Job
Then the job should be built by the one agent

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When adding a group or user in global or plan permissions, Bamboo does not check for case sensitivity of the added name. However, names are case sensitive when used to verify if the user or group has permission.

h3. Environment
When using LDAP user repositories or Crowd

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a group/user named _MixedCase_ in Crowd
# Add group/user _mixedcase_ in Bamboo Global or Plan Permission Access

h3. Expected Results
Bamboo should throw a _Group not found_ error as the cases does not match

h3. Actual Results
The group/user is added successfully to the global/user permission. However, users/groups will still have no access as usernames group names are supposed to be case sensitive

h3.Workaround
* When adding group/user permission, ensure that they are in the correct case 
* Alternatively, configure groups to use lower case in Bamboo and enforce lower case in Crowd
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Enforcing+Lower-Case+Usernames+and+Groups+for+an+Application
fields.summary: Usernames and Groups are not case sensitive when adding it to global or plan permissions

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently, if:
* a job/plan/project is dedicated to a particular agent/image config, and
* that job has requirements that the dedicated agent/image config does not match

then a warning will be shown, but it will not point to (what may well be) the true problem: that the job/plan/project is dedicated to a particular agent/image config that does not match the requirements.

Also, if there are agents online where the capabilities match but they're dedicated to a different plan -- it could be clearer that the reason no agents can build it is due to existing dediations

h3. Suggested Solution
The warning should advise about the dedication and provide links to:
* the page that allows the user to configure the dedication, and
* the page to view the capabilities of the dedicated agent/image config.

An additional warning present when there are agents online where the capabilities match, however they are dedicated to other plans / projects
fields.summary: Show agent dedication details on job requirements page

fields.description:
Currently Bamboo menu dropdowns seem limited to non configurable size while there appears to be extra room on the page for these. Some examples are release name, deployment environment, branch name, repository name, etc.

It would be nice if the width of these dropdowns was configurable at a UI level to better utilize available screen real estate.

This is especially useful for clients following strict naming conventions in which there are very longs names and the beginning of the names is similar.
fields.summary: Allow for variable picker width

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Remote triggers from BitBucket are working when you create a service, even after you disable or remove the trigger from the build, provided the 'service' is still in BitBucket.

This is not expected, as no trigger is available.


h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a build plan in Bamboo
# Connect it with a repository in BitBucket
# Create a 'Remote Trigger' in the build and 'service' in BitBucket to have BitBucket automatically trigger the plan, as explained [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/repository-triggers-the-build-when-changes-are-committed-289276902.html]
# Testing is a good idea, to see if it works
# Delete or disable the 'Remote Trigger' from the plan (do not remove the service in BitBucket)
# Commit to the repository

h3. Expected Results
# The plan is not built, as the trigger is not longer there (or active)

h3. Actual Results
# The build is triggered.
 
h3.Workaround
Remove the service in BitBucket as well.
fields.summary: Builds will be triggered on changes in BitBucket even if the 'Remote Trigger' is no longer available

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When a plan has a branch (not only _master_) and more than one stage, after selecting the job results from one of the stages, two problems happen:
# The Plan vanishes in the top path
# The _View all branches_ link leads to a _Page no found_ page when you're not on the _master_ branch

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Have a plan with at least one branch enabled
# Add a second stage with valid jobs on both stages
# Successfully run this plan on both _master_ and _branch_
# On the _Build result_ screen for the branch select the job in one of the stages (see screenshots for details)

h3. Expected Results
The plan should appear on the top path and the _View all branches_ link should take us to the plan's branches.

h3. Actual Results
The plan isn't displayed in the top path (see screenshots) and the _View all branches_ link takes us to a _Page not found_ page.
 
h3. Notes
When the _Build result_ screen is selected, the (working) _View all branches_ link is like https://<instance>.atlassian.net/builds/browse/<PROJECT-ID>-<PLAN-ID>/branches
However, when the _Job result_ screen is selected (after clicking one of the stage's jobs) the link to the _View all branches_ is https://<instance>.atlassian.net/builds/browse/<PROJECT-ID>\-<PLAN-ID><BRANCH-ID>-<BUILD-ID>/branches which leads to a _Page not found_ page.
fields.summary: Link to 'View all branches' on a branche's stage give a 'Page not found' error

fields.description: With 5.9.4 bamboo verbosity about the build preparation dumped on the logs have been heavily increased (in comparison with 5.5.0). According to support "The information you are now seeing in the build logs are related to what Bamboo can use as capability in the build/deployment along with extra environment variables and they are important for troubleshooting reasons." This info is not necessarily important for me as software builder, so there should be an option in bamboo to specify the "system" verbosity level that is dumped to the build logfile.
fields.summary: Allow to specify verbosity level in logfiles

fields.description:
I use a lot of shared-artifact-download tasks in a lot of different jobs. Those shared-artifacts are from previous stages of the same plan.

When I clone this plan, I find that I need to redefine all sources of every artifact-download task to grab it from the newly-cloned plan. I expected instead that when I clone a plan, that the new jobs identify that it is an Intra-plan-artifact-download (can I use the word "Intra-plan"), that the artifact-download source would point to the same plan. Not the plan that was previously made.
fields.summary: Cloned plans artifact-download sources (if intra-plan artifacts) should transfer to new plan

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Suppose you have Bamboo "Build Plan" set up to delete "Plan Branches" in case it detects that a branch has been removed from the remote repository after a certain period of time (say the default 7 days).

In case you remove the branch from the repository and Bamboo detects the branch removal, it will delete the "Plan Branch" after 7 days even if you recreate the Branch on the remote repository in between.

h3. Details of a use case
Notes from a Bamboo user:
{quote}
I had a branch plan that was disabled (as expected) after the underlying git branch was removed (merged to master). The next day I re-created the git branch and manually went and re-enabled the disabled branch plan and kicked off a new build with my new changes.

About an hour later, my branch plan was just about to finish but then the page auto-refreshed and showed me a 'page not found' error. The branch plan had been deleted by the 3am scheduled clean-up. I confirmed this from the server logs:
{noformat}
2015-09-15 03:01:04,003 INFO [scheduler_Worker-8] [BranchExpiryJob] Deleting Plan Branch 'Puppet Continuous Deployment - Puppet CD - BUILDENG-9109-downloads-known-hosts' of Plan 'Puppet Continuous Deployment - Puppet CD' since the VCS branch was deleted 1 days ago.
{noformat}

At this point in time, the branch and branch plan were not deleted or inactive, so it is expected that Bamboo should not have deleted it.
{quote}

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Install Bamboo and Stash
# Connect them via AppLinks
# Create a "Build Plan" and link it to one of your repositories in Stash
# Configure the [Automatic branch management section|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bamboo/using-plan-branches-289276872.html#Usingplanbranches-Automaticbranchmanagement] of your "Build Plan" to *Create plan branches for all new branches*. That will automatically set up the *Delete branches after a period of time* for 7 days.
# Create a new branch on your repository [from within the Bitbucket server UI|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServer/Using+branches+in+Bitbucket+Server#UsingbranchesinBitbucketServer-Creatingbranches]
# Notice that Bamboo will create a "Plan Branch"
# Delete the "Plan Branch" from [the Bitbucket server UI|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServer/Using+branches+in+Bitbucket+Server#UsingbranchesinBitbucketServer-Managingallyourbranches]
# Notice that your "Plan Branch" will be disabled by Bamboo as it detected the branch was removed
# Recreate the branch [from within the Bitbucket server UI|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServer/Using+branches+in+Bitbucket+Server#UsingbranchesinBitbucketServer-Creatingbranches] before the expiry date for deleted branches (7 days in this specific example)


h3. Expected Results
# The "Plan branch" should be reenabled by Bamboo
# The "Plan branch" shouldn't be marked for deletion anymore
# Bamboo deletes a "Plan branch" that *is enabled*

h3. Actual Results
# The "Plan branch" is _not_ reenabled upon recreation on the remote repo
# The branch is deleted according to the "Plan Branch" set up despite the fact it was recreated on the remote repo
# Bamboo _shouldn't_ delete a "Plan branch" that is *enabled*
 
h3.Workaround
1. You could check which branch has been detected for deletion:
{noformat}
bamboo=# select * from vcs_branch;
 vcs_branch_id |          name           | detected_deletion_date  | chain_id 
---------------+-------------------------+-------------------------+----------
       1867783 | bugfix/thirdnewbranch   |                         |  1474568
       1867784 | bugfix/anewbranch       |                         |  1474568
       1867785 | bugfix/branch           |                         |  1474568
       1867786 | bugfix/athirdnewbranch  |                         |  1474568
       1867787 | bugfix/asecondnewbranch |                         |  1474568
       1867788 | master                  |                         |  1474568
       1867789 | bugfix/branchtest       | 2015-10-08 10:22:52.241 |  1474568
       1867790 | bugfix/branch           | 2015-10-08 10:31:44.442 |  1474568
{noformat}
2. Then you can set the {{detected_deletion_date}} to NULL:
{noformat}
update vcs_branch set detected_deletion_date=NULL where vcs_branch_id=1867790;
{noformat}
3. Check it again that the branch has not been marked for deletion:
{noformat}
bamboo=# select * from vcs_branch;
 vcs_branch_id |          name           | detected_deletion_date  | chain_id 
---------------+-------------------------+-------------------------+----------
       1867783 | bugfix/thirdnewbranch   |                         |  1474568
       1867784 | bugfix/anewbranch       |                         |  1474568
       1867785 | bugfix/branch           |                         |  1474568
       1867786 | bugfix/athirdnewbranch  |                         |  1474568
       1867787 | bugfix/asecondnewbranch |                         |  1474568
       1867788 | master                  |                         |  1474568
       1867789 | bugfix/branchtest       | 2015-10-08 10:22:52.241 |  1474568
       1867790 | bugfix/branch           |                         |  1474568
{noformat}
4. You can manually reenable the "Plan Branch" by using the Bamboo UI
fields.summary: Bamboo doesn't recognise when a deleted branch is recreated in the remote repo

fields.description:
We're using c3.2xlarge spot instances, which have been enduring extreme price spikes. Amazon's "On Demand" price for c3.2xlarge instances is $0.42/hour, but people have been bidding up to $4/hour, killing our instances and ruining our throughput.

Typically these price spikes affect just one or two availability zones at a time; our images are configured to use multiple availability zones (by using multiple VPC subnets).

It would be a huge help if Bamboo would launch our spot instances in the cheapest availability zone.
fields.summary: Select the cheapest spot-price VPC availability zone

fields.description:
My error message is as follows:

{{File /tai/bamboo/bamboo-agent-home/xml-data/build-dir/INF-CLEAN-CC61/cleanuptask.xml was ignored because it was modified (2015-09-08 15:45:50.000) before task started (2015-09-08 15:45:50.513)}}

As you can see, the file time-stamp is only accurate to the exact second. Time stamps on the file system are truncated to the nearest second. Knowing when the task started is accurate to the millisecond. To compare one truncated number to a non-truncated number and that comparison causing a build failure is an unfair comparison.

I recommend you detect whether that file was created before the task started, by using the task-start-time by truncating both numbers, as defined by the file system.
fields.summary: JUnit parser makes unfair modification-date comparison.

fields.description:

For security reason, it is not secure to send SSH key files over HTTP(s).

It would be better if there is an option to set the SCP task to scan a directory path in the machine hosting Bamboo to get the SSH key.
fields.summary: Scan path for SSH key when setting SCP task

fields.description:
I often work with multiple teams. Occasionally other teams have different branch naming rules which means the branch that I create may not get picked up by automatic plan branch creation.

When I manually create a plan branch my workflow is as such:

1. Find build I'm interested in creating a plan branch for.
2. Navigate to the "view all branches" via a drop down. (I have literally no idea what informs that drop down but it's almost never what I want. Maybe it's things I navigated to recently? I guess I want a mix of that and recently created/updated branches in the hope that mine will show up there after I commit)
3. After I wait forever for the "view all branches" page to load, I ctrl-f for the branch I'm looking for. If it's not there I continue…
4. Click on Actions.
5. Click on Configure Plan (which is a weird thing to do but I've figured it out from experience).
6. Click branches.
7. Click Create plan branch.
8. Immediately scroll to the bottom because it'll never be at the top.
9. Click More…
10. Scroll again and click More…
10. Scroll again and click More…
10. Scroll again and click More…
10. Scroll again and click More…
11. I do this a bunch of times so that I can use ctrl-f to look for what I actually want. I do this for several reasons. Scrolling and clicking more is a very repeatable action but scrolling, clicking and searching, not finding, then going back to scrolling is slower. I want a higher chance of finding when I search.
12. Click on the checkbox for the branch that I want to create a plan branch for. If I happen to want to create more than one plan branch I never do it by using the check boxes because doing that creates them both but then I have to navigate back to the "view all" thing to enable them (I'm gonna complain about having to enable them more later…).
13. Wait for ages for the plan branch that I've just created to load. 
14. Enable the plan. (I have to enable the thing I just created …is this real life?)
15. Guess which thing I need to click in order to get to the page where I will see the plan running instead of a configuration screen. Seriously, some links that look and sound the same in bamboo go different places depending on whether your in configuration or not, it's weird.

I'd like this process to be less painful.

Thanks.
fields.summary: Make plan branch manual creation faster.

fields.description:

1) Create a plan branch named after a git branch that it is tracking (eg both named branch-1)
2) Disable all the automatic cleanup for that branch

The bamboo branch now disables itself as it thinks its source branch is gone.

I also found a branch that was created back in 2013 which caused the exact same pattern:

!Screen Shot 2015-09-07 at 1.42.51 pm.png!

fields.summary: Freemarker error when triggering defaultBuildRequirement.action

fields.description: Currently you can disable build plans and even build tasks, but the same cannot be done with the triggers. This applies to triggers for both Deployment and Build Plans. This would be a much appreciated feature to have, instead of having to delete the trigger, and re-creating it.
fields.summary: Add ability to disable deployment and build plan triggers

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Some users may request Bamboo to allow disabling use of default exclude patterns ({{.git}}, {{.svn}}, etc) for artifacts.

Bamboo uses [Ant file copy pattern|http://ant.apache.org/manual/dirtasks.html] for 'Copy pattern' of artifact definitions. It has a set of definitions called Default Excludes that are excluded by default (see Default Excludes section of [Ant file copy pattern|http://ant.apache.org/manual/dirtasks.html]).

h3. Workaround
Change the name of the files/directories while archiving (e.g. {{.git}} -> {{git}}), and set {{.git}} at the 'Destination path' of the following 'Artifact download' task so that the artifact is downloaded as {{.git}} (see WorkAround.jpg).

h3. Note
The same request was raised to Jenkins and it was already implemented:
https://issues.jenkins-ci.org/browse/JENKINS-20086
fields.summary: Allow disabling use of default exclude patterns (.git, .svn, etc) for artifacts

fields.description:
In Bamboo v5.9.x (_fresh install_) the option to quarantine a test result is not available.

h2. Reproduce
# install *Bamboo v5.8.1*
# create a Project (_i.e.: Code_), Plan (_i.e.: Maven_)
# download [^maven.tar.gz] to the project/plan
# run build
The build is going to fail when running a test and the "{{Quarantine}}" option {color:green}*IS*{color} available
!bamboo-v58x.png|thumbnail!

h2. Reproduce (fresh install)
# install *Bamboo v5.9.4*
# create a Project (_i.e.: Code_), Plan (_i.e.: Maven_)
# download [^maven.tar.gz] to the project/plan
# run build
The build is going to fail when running a test and the "{{Quarantine}}" option {color:red}*IS NOT*{color} available
|!bamboo-v59x.png|thumbnail!

h2. Reproduce (from upgrade)
# export Bamboo v5.8.1 with tests in quarantine
# install Bamboo v5.9.4
# import to upgrade
# go to Project (_i.e.: Code_), Plan (_i.e.: Maven_)
# run build
The build is going to fail when running a test and the "{{Quarantine}}" option {color:green}*IS*{color} available
|!bamboo-v594-quarantine.png|thumbnail!

h2. New Feature
Bamboo v5.9.x has a new feature where you can enable/disable Quarantine under "{{Bamboo administration >> Overview >> Plans >> Quarantine settings}}". Please, enable it and the Quarantine option will become available in the UI.
fields.summary: Quarantine option is not available in UI

fields.description:
h1. Improvement
Ability to see the outstanding code revisions per build and any revisions that are checked into the repository associated with the build that has not been built.
fields.summary: See Outstanding Check In's for Bamboo

fields.description:
Oh, wow, now that I need it, I'm so excited to use this "Test Summary" page. We see a great benefit to our systems.

Hopefully, our agents are configured identically. That's the ideal case, but in our case, that's not reality. I am trusting that our tests don't break because of certain hardware problems between agents (smaller RAM, fewer CPU, smaller disk, different JRE or JDK versions, missing dependencies, etc).

In the Test Summary, we found that one of our tests usually failed when run on a certain agent. It's a crash in our application, probably from a memory leak, we're still not sure. Although there is a trend to have it trigger on a certain agent, it has crashed on a different one also.

What I'm asking for, is that alongside the failing cases (on the bottom), that the corresponding Agent is also listed. This would provide valuable information about the source of the problem, in case it is a problem with the Agent.

I do not believe that the agent needs to be linkable, like you would move into an administration point of view or whatev. That is a lot less valuable. The important part is just having the data shown without having to dig into each case.
fields.summary: Test Summary data missing "Agent" that found the error

fields.description:
The wallboard needs a rework. I should be able to generate wallboards the same way I create bamboo plans; with an arbitrary number wallboards managed by project admins that subscribe to any branch of any plan in the bamboo ecosystem. We currently have 167 plans across multiple teams and asking 8 different users to create a favorite wallboard and then keep a system logged in at all times to that users account to display their wallboard is ridiculous.

Additionally, I should be able to set permissions on these plans (even something as simple as public, private) to facilitate anonymous access control.
fields.summary: Wallboard has very limited functionality

fields.description: Running a deployment build with a 'Command' task will run forever until canceled if the 'Argument' parameter is left empty. I think it would be more user friendly to prevent this from happening. Is there a case where you would want the 'argument' field to be left blank?
fields.summary: Executing Command task with empty field builds forever until canceled

fields.description:
In a build project --> configure plan --> permissions:

Click 'Add Group' button.

There is not auto-complete for the 'Add Group' text field, which does not match the behavior of the 'Add User' text field. We would also like to have groups show up when we start to type.
fields.summary: Autocomplete on 'add group' permissions text field

fields.description: Tooltip should touch build number element, so I can click some element inside it:
fields.summary: Can't click on build number tooltip

fields.description:
When a plan is building, triggers resulting from new commits are not queued.
The result is that the new commits are not being build.

To reproduce:
# Create a Bamboo plan which uses a Stash repo, and uses the default "Stash repository triggered" trigger.
# Create a job that:
## Checks out the repo.
## Script task with "sleep 60" to make the build last about 60 seconds.
# Commit and push some changes to the repo.
# Bamboo is triggered by the repo change, and starts building.
# While the build is still running, commit and push another change to the repo.
# After the build finished, the second commit is never picked up by Bamboo.
fields.summary: Stash triggers should be queued while build is running

fields.description:
Occasionally deployments can get stuck, and there's nothing that can be done to stop them. The only known fix is restarting the server. 

The logs display:

{noformat}No logs found.{noformat}

If a stop has been requested, the stop button will be greyed out and display: {{"Build is currently being stopped... If there is no response you may need to kill the build manually."}}. 

No new deployment of the affected project can be done until the broken one has been cleared.
fields.summary: Deployment never completes, and fails to terminate when stop requested

fields.description:
A logical step after a successful deployment is to run functional tests (ie. smoke tests) over an environment.

I have searched answers.atlassian.com and this does not seem to be supported, even though build plans can trigger other tasks with ease.

This is a core piece in the CI / CD pipeline that appears to be missing.

Please let me know if this will be available in a future version of Bamboo, or why this can't (or shouldn't) be implemented.
fields.summary: Stash: Allow deployment plans to trigger other tasks

fields.description:
When a powershell command attempts to prompt for user input the task just hangs (as there is no user to provide the input to the prompt dialog).

Powershell supports the {{-NonInteractive}} argument on its command line which disables the ability for commands to attempt to prompt. Unfortunately I do not believe it is possible to enable that non-interactive mode from *within* a running powershell session.
fields.summary: Allow running (or always run) powershell script tasks with the -NonInteractive argument set.

fields.description:
I am reviewing the logs of a failed build.

The offending command in question is REALLY long. So long that my screen is not wide enough to display the whole line.

Unfortunately, the Bamboo WebUI doesn't provide me with a horizontal scrollbar. So, now I can't see the full command that was run.

I have even tried to decrease the font size. Two problems:
* This is a horrible experience for the user
* The offending command was so long that Chrome wouldn't let me shrink the text anymore

Please add a horizontal scrollbar to the WebUI.

For reference, the failing Bamboo build is https://engservices-bamboo.internal.atlassian.com/browse/PEI-MPLLICCB-JDK1805X64-21/log and the line in question is at "31-Aug-2015 23:28:03".
I have attached a screenshot of the relevant line. You can see that the line does get wrapped, but textbox is much wider than my screen.

I have also attached a screenshot of the same line as displayed in the "View full logs" screen for comparison.
fields.summary: Add an horizontal scroll in Logs tab

fields.description:
h1. Description
Retrieving http://localhost:8085/rest/api/latest/result/TEST-TEST.json?expand=results.result.vcsRevisions.vcsRevision.changes.change fails with NullPointerException when it contains a build referencing a commit and the corresponding repository has been deleted. However, displaying the build, commit etc. in the web interface seems to work.

{noformat}
java.lang.NullPointerException
    at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.rest.model.build.change.RestChange.expand(RestChange.java:134)
    at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.rest.model.build.change.RestChangeExpander.expandInternal(RestChangeExpander.java:12)
    at com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.rest.model.build.change.RestChangeExpander.expandInternal(RestChangeExpander.java:5)
    at com.atlassian.plugins.rest.common.expand.AbstractRecursiveEntityExpander.expand(AbstractRecursiveEntityExpander.java:9)
[...]
{noformat}


h1. Reproduce the issue
* Create a new Plan (e.g. TEST) using a Git or Subversion repository (Job with only checkout task suffices)
* Trigger the build of the plan manually
* Commit and push a change to the repository
* Let Bamboo build the plan with the change (using Repository polling trigger)
* Modify the plan: remove repository 
* Might be optional: add the same repository again
* Open REST URL http://localhost:8085/rest/api/latest/result/TEST-TEST.json?expand=results.result.vcsRevisions.vcsRevision.changes.change (assuming both project and job have key "TEST")
fields.summary: REST: Exception when expanding RestChange

This will affect older custom images which were created when Java 6 was still the default JDK installed in Atlassian instances.

h3.Workaround
Install *JDK8u45* and make sure that JAVA_HOME is properly set system-wide to point at *JDK8u45*. This will allow the Bamboo Agent to start up again normally.

fields.description: From 5.8 to 5.9, deploymentExecutionService's api was changed in a backwards incompatible manner.  Previously execute took a deploymentContext, but in 5.9 it was changed to take an environment and an EnvironmentTriggeringAction.  Furthermore, there doesnt' appear to be any way in the plugin api to create an EnvironmentTriggeringAction as it's an interface and EnvironmentTriggeringActionFactory can't be wired in as a dependency.
fields.summary: Bamboo API: Backwards compatibility broken in 5.9 for DeploymentExecutionService

fields.description:
When you have parallel jobs in a stage, there may be causes where it doesn't make sense to continue building if one fails.  

It would be useful if a stage could be configured to abort remaining jobs when one fails.  Not only does this provide faster feedback to developers about the breakage, it also makes the resources available to be used for other build plans. This is especially important when the jobs take a very long time to complete.
fields.summary: Option to terminate parallel jobs if one fails

fields.description:
When one or more parallel jobs in a stage of a running build plan has failed, it would be useful to have quick visual indication from the toplevel list of build plans.  

One possibility would be to change the spinning icon from blue to red.
fields.summary: Change "running build" icon when parallel job has failed
Improve build result summary status for manually stopped builds

fields.description: At the moment Bamboo lists the SHA1 of git commits. This would be way more useful if it had hyperlinks to github or the equivalent instead
fields.summary: As a developer, I would like to have hyperlinks to github.ihs for each commit in Bamboo's list of changes

fields.description:
h3. Summary
If Bamboo hit into UnresolvedAddressException for a lot of time when accessing Stash, it may hit into "Too many open files" error later

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Set the hostname test.atlassian.com to Stash (can use /etc/hosts)
# Create Application Link between Stash and Bamboo
# Make sure that the repository is added successfully into Bamboo
# Delete the hostname test.atlassian.com
# Build a Plan in Bamboo that uses Stash repository
# Wait for it to fail
# Check open files with the commands "lsof -p <BAMBOO_PID>"
# Repeat step 5-7 for a lot of time

h3. Expected Results
The open files that connect to Stash should be released after the failure

h3. Actual Results
The open files keep on increasing

h3. Notes
If there are a lot of Repositories in Bamboo connecting to Stash, the open files will keep on increasing until it hit into "Too many open files" error

h3.Workaround

Assuming that the address reported in the {{UnresolvedAddressException}} is incorrect because you've migrated Bitbucket to a new address, you can replace the URL Bamboo is using to access Bitbucket using these steps:
# Shutdown Bamboo
# Backup database for rollback purposes
# Run the following SQL to change the hostname:
{code:sql}
UPDATE VCS_LOCATION SET XML_DEFINITION_DATA=REPLACE(XML_DEFINITION_DATA,"old_hostname","new_hostname");
{code}
# Restart Bamboo

Alternatively, if the address is correct and still can't be resolved -- you'll need to investigate why your DNS infrastructure does not correctly resolve the address.
fields.summary: UnresolvedAddressException will cause "Too many open files" error

fields.description:
When connected to a Bitbucket with 2FA enabled, the following error is thrown when trying to _Load Repositories_:
{code}Failed to load data from Bitbucket. com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.hg.bitbucket.api.BitbucketApiException: {"error": {"message": "Resource not found", "detail": "There is no API hosted at this URL.\n\nFor information about our API's, please refer to the documentation at: https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/IYBGDQ"}}{code}

Issue only happens when using _BitBucket_ type repositories and trying to load the list of repositories. Specifying a clone URL manually works normally.

h5. Workaround
Use _Git_ type repository instead and define the clone URL through SSH or HTTPS.
fields.summary: Bamboo "Load Repositories" breaks with Bitbucket 2 factor auth

fields.description:
Currently Bamboo escapes files it sends via SCP to a remote server with single quote. On Windows, depending on:
* SSH server and its configuration escaped path is not handled properly, as a result file arrived on host server is wrapped with single quote, e.g  'my_app.exe'

Scope of the issue:
* Provide better support for cases when SSH server can't handle paths properly. 

*Workaround*
The following server handle path properly:
* [Cygwin SSH Server|https://www.cygwin.com/]
* [MobaSSH|http://mobassh.mobatek.net/]
fields.summary: Provide better support for SCP to Windows servers

fields.description:
h3. Issue
When running Bamboo v5.9.x with Java JDK v1.8.60 "{{Amazon S3 bucket}}" in "{{AWS CodeDeploy}}" task does not display a list of buckets.

h3. Workaround 1
# please, visit http://mvnrepository.com/artifact/joda-time/joda-time/2.8.2 and download "{{joda-time-2.8.2.jar}}"
# please, stop Bamboo
# please, go to "{{<bamboo-install>/atlassian-bamboo/WEB-INF/lib/}}"
#* please, move away "{{joda-time-2.3.jar}}" from this directory
#* please, place "{{joda-time-2.8.2.jar}}" in the current directory
# please, start Bamboo

h3. Workaround 2
# Run Bamboo with Java JDK v1.8.45.
fields.summary: Unable to interact with Amazon S3 bucket on Java 8u60+
